free_text.Learning outcomes: The course is an introduction to optimization theory, aimed at helping the students to appropriately use optimization algorithms and packages. The stress will be made on methodological issues and results analysis[br/]
free_text.Content: 1.	Introduction to optimization[br/][li]Modeling, problem transformations[br/]2.	Unconstrained optimization: [br/][li]Problem analysis[br/][li]Problem definition[br/][li]Convexity / concavity; differentiability[br/][li]Conditioning and preconditioning[br/]3.	Unconstrained optimization: optimality conditions[br/]4.	Solving systems of nonlinear equations[br/][li]Newton's method[br/][li]Quasi-Newton methods[br/]5.	Unconstrained optimization: algorithms[br/][li]Quadratic problems: conjugate gradients[br/][li]Linesearch [br/][li]Trust region[br/][li]Quasi-Newton methods[br/][li]Least squares problems - Kalman filter[br/]6.	Constrained optimization : problem analysis[br/][li]Active constraints[br/][li]Constraints qualification[br/][li]Constraints elimination[br/]7.	Introduction to duality
free_text.Bibliography and material: Bierlaire, M. Introduction à l'optimisation différentiable, PPUR (2006) [br/]D. P. Bertsekas, Nonlinear programming, Athena Scientific, 1995[br/]
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Mandatory : Analyse III, Physique générale I, Physique générale II, Probability and statistics
